article: How to Kill Roaches with Borax or Boric Acid
intro: If you’re tired of surprise roaches scurrying across your floors and up your walls, borax is a lifesaver. This natural powdery substance, also called sodium tetraborate, kills insects like roaches, and it’s easy to use. In this article, we’ll show you how to identify roach hot-spots and apply bug-busting borax or boric acid mixtures, all while keeping your pets and kids safe. Read on to get rid of roaches once and for all!

steps.title: Keep your borax mixtures dry instead of making a spray with water.
steps.subtitle: Some people recommend mixing borax with water to make an easy-to-apply spray. However, moisture makes borax less effective against roaches since part of what makes borax so deadly is its ability to rapidly dehydrate insects. To keep it as potent as possible, make sure it stays dry during storage and after application.
sub-points: If any area you apply borax to becomes wet, reapply more dry borax powder to the problem spot.

steps.title: Wipe down treated areas with a damp cloth before using the surface.
steps.subtitle: Although borax isn’t fatal in small doses, it can still cause irritation, nausea, and other side effects when ingested. To avoid this, dampen a cloth and wipe down any surfaces you need to use or prepare food on thoroughly, then go over them again with an all-purpose cleaner or hot, soapy water to eliminate any roach bacteria.
sub-points: Alternatively, spritz the powder with water so it won’t billow into the air, then wipe it up with a damp cloth.
Reapply borax if roaches are still a problem. It’s a relatively slow-acting insecticide, but an extremely effective one. Continue repeating the treatment until the roaches are gone.

steps.title: Filter out the boric acid crystals and lay them out to dry overnight.
steps.subtitle: Pour your boric acid crystals and the acidic saltwater they’re now sitting in through a funnel with a paper filter inside. Once all the water has drained out of the filter, lift it out of the funnel and place it on top of a clean cloth. Tear open the filter and spread the boric acid crystals out in a thin layer (using a non-cooking stirring rod or gloved hands) to dry overnight.
sub-points: Drain the water into a separate container (not straight into the drain) since it is acidic and toxic. Neutralize it by adding baking soda—when a  says the water is about 7pH (neutral), it’s safe to pour down the drain.
Make sure no pets or children can access the drying boric acid crystals. Place them in a locked room, on a high shelf, or in another safe area.
Once the crystals are fully dried, place them in a clean, dry, clearly labeled container for storage.
